pageContext.description:
Shown as a seated half-length figure the Virgin supports the naked infant Christ who stands on one leg on her knee and looks out at the viewer smiling. The child holds an apple in his right hand, while more are visible in the top right corner hanging from the tree. The Virgin's hair is covered by a transparent veil and the slight inclination of her head betrays her motherly affection. At the right edge of the image an expansive landscape is visible with a castle on a rocky outcrop. 
[cda 2015]

metadata.title: Virgin under the apple tree

pageContext.provenance:
- acquired in 1820, probably from landgraviate property 

[Cat. Darmstadt 1990, No. 69]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- the retouching has darkened on a split running down from the top edge of the painting 
[condition report, Hessisches Landesmuseum 1980]

- the joins are clearly visible on the front of the panel
- on the reverse the joins were reinforced with strips of canvas (two cover the entire length, two only half the length) 
- formerly the panel exhibited three cross-members, that have left marks visible today on the reverse of the panel 
- at the left edge the panel has been trimmed slightly, the top and bottom edges are probably original and a barb has been retained along the right edge 
- the reverse exhibits a glazed, greyish-green oil coating over the joins 
- viewed from the recto the panel exhibits a convex curve
- extensive woodworm damage above all in the lower section of the panel
- at the bottom left edge the groove is damaged, it was considerably weakened by the woodworm damage 
- hand palm sized retouching in the sky in the top left corner has darkened considerably 
- extensive retouching in the flesh paint 
- the edges are in part damaged 

[Condition report, Hessisches Landesmuseum 1989]

tests.text:
- the panel consists of five planks, butt-joined 
- a groove is present on all four sides (between 0.3 and 1 cm in width) 
- coarse marks from a block plane runnig horizontally across the reverse of the panel

- a barb from the ground has been retained along the right edge 
[Condition report , Hessisches Landesmuseum 1989]

- an underdrawing executed with a brush is clearly visible; there was a small change made to the position of the Virgin's hand 
- the underdrawing consists of short and longer brushstrokes, loose and confident 
[Report, Bernd Konrad 1990]

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia at the top right on the tree: serpent with elevated wings, facing right
[cda 2015]
